abies_concolor.description: An evergreen conifer with a conical crown and beautiful blue-green needles, often used as ornamental trees and Christmas trees.
abies_concolor.features: Tall evergreen tree with soft blue-green needles arranged in flat sprays. Bark is smooth and gray, becoming deeply furrowed with age.

abies_nordmanniana.description: Popular Christmas tree known for excellent needle retention and symmetrical shape.
abies_nordmanniana.features: Deep green glossy needles with silvery undersides. Forms a perfect pyramidal shape with horizontal branches.

acer_campestre.description: Small deciduous tree with dense, rounded crown often used in hedgerows.
acer_campestre.features: Small, five-lobed leaves that turn yellow in autumn. Corky bark and distinctive winged fruits (samaras).

acer_ginnala.description: Small deciduous tree with excellent fall color, often grown as a multi-stemmed shrub.
acer_ginnala.features: Three-lobed leaves that turn brilliant scarlet in autumn. Fragrant flowers and red-winged samaras in summer.

acer_griseum.description: Ornamental tree prized for its exfoliating cinnamon-colored bark.
acer_griseum.features: Trifoliate leaves turn brilliant orange-red in autumn. Distinctive peeling, papery bark in cinnamon to reddish-brown colors.

acer_negundo.description: Fast-growing deciduous tree with compound leaves, often considered a weedy species but adaptable to many conditions.
acer_negundo.features: Compound leaves with 3-7 leaflets, unlike most other maples. Produces abundant winged seeds (samaras) and has opposite branching pattern.

acer_palmatum.description: Small deciduous tree prized for its elegance and beautiful foliage that changes colors throughout the seasons.
acer_palmatum.features: Delicate, palmate leaves with 5-9 pointed lobes in various colors from red to green to variegated. Creates a graceful silhouette with layered branching.

acer_pensylvanicum.description: Small understory tree with distinctive vertically striped bark and large, three-lobed leaves.
acer_pensylvanicum.features: Smooth greenish bark with white stripes that gives it the common name 'snakebark maple'. Three-lobed leaves can be up to 6 inches long.

acer_platanoides.description: Medium to large deciduous tree widely planted as a street tree, with some varieties becoming invasive in North America.
acer_platanoides.features: Dense, rounded crown with 5-lobed leaves similar to sycamore. Produces milky sap when leaf petiole is broken, distinguishing it from other maples.

acer_pseudoplatanus.description: Large deciduous tree with spreading crown and distinctive flaking bark, tolerant of urban conditions and coastal exposure.
acer_pseudoplatanus.features: Five-lobed leaves with irregular teeth and purplish-red fall color. Distinctive flaking bark that reveals orange-brown inner bark.

acer_rubrum.description: Medium to large deciduous tree known for its brilliant red fall color and early spring red flowers.
acer_rubrum.features: Three to five-lobed leaves with serrated edges that turn brilliant scarlet in fall. Produces small red flowers in early spring before leaves emerge.

acer_saccharinum.description: Fast-growing deciduous tree with silvery undersides to its leaves that flash in the breeze.
acer_saccharinum.features: Deeply cut, five-lobed leaves with silvery-white undersides. Branches have a graceful, somewhat weeping habit.

acer_saccharum.description: Iconic deciduous tree known for its spectacular fall color and as the source of maple syrup.
acer_saccharum.features: Five-lobed leaves with few teeth that turn brilliant orange, yellow, and red in fall. Produces sweet sap that is harvested for maple syrup.

aesculus_flava.description: Large deciduous tree with showy yellow flowers and glossy, palmate compound leaves.
aesculus_flava.features: Compound leaves with 5-7 leaflets arranged like fingers on a hand. Produces upright clusters of yellow flowers followed by smooth (not spiny) seed capsules.

aesculus_glabra.description: Medium-sized deciduous tree with palmate compound leaves and greenish-yellow flowers, state tree of Ohio.
aesculus_glabra.features: Compound leaves with 5 leaflets that turn orange to red in fall. Produces upright clusters of greenish-yellow flowers and spiny fruit capsules containing shiny brown seeds.

aesculus_hippocastamon.description: Large deciduous tree with showy white flower clusters and spiny fruit capsules containing shiny brown seeds.
aesculus_hippocastamon.features: Large compound leaves with 5-7 leaflets that radiate from a central point. Produces large, upright clusters of white flowers with yellow and pink markings.

aesculus_pavi.description: Small deciduous tree or large shrub with striking red tubular flowers that attract hummingbirds.
aesculus_pavi.features: Palmate compound leaves with 5 leaflets. Produces tubular red flowers in upright clusters during spring, followed by smooth (not spiny) seed capsules.

ailanthus_altissima.description: Fast-growing deciduous tree often considered invasive in North America and Europe, known for its ability to thrive in harsh urban environments.
ailanthus_altissima.features: Large compound leaves with 11-41 leaflets that give off a strong, unpleasant odor when crushed. Produces clusters of reddish-green fruits with twisted wings.

albizia_julibrissin.description: Deciduous tree with umbrella-like canopy and fern-like compound leaves. Known for its showy pink pom-pom like flowers that bloom in summer.
albizia_julibrissin.features: Feathery, bipinnate leaves that fold at night or when touched. Produces fluffy pink flowers with silky thread-like stamens that resemble pom-poms.

amelanchier_arborea.description: Small deciduous tree or large shrub valued for its early spring white flowers, edible berries, and fall color.
amelanchier_arborea.features: Smooth gray bark, oval leaves with fine teeth that emerge with downy hairs. White star-shaped flowers in early spring followed by edible purple-black berries.

amelanchier_canadensis.description: Multi-stemmed deciduous tree or shrub known for early spring flowers, edible fruits, and autumn color.
amelanchier_canadensis.features: Oval leaves with fine teeth, showy white flowers in spring, and purple-black edible berries in summer. Smooth gray bark with vertical striping.

amelanchier_laevis.description: Small deciduous tree with showy white flowers in early spring, followed by edible purple-black fruits.
amelanchier_laevis.features: Young leaves emerge with reddish-purple hue, distinguishing it from other serviceberries. Produces clusters of white flowers followed by sweet, edible berries.

asimina_triloba.description: Small understory tree that produces the largest edible fruit native to North America, with tropical-looking leaves.
asimina_triloba.features: Large, drooping oblong leaves that turn bright yellow in fall. Produces unusual maroon flowers that give way to large, custard-like fruits with a flavor resembling banana and mango.

betula_alleghaniensis.description: Medium to large deciduous tree known for its golden, peeling bark and wintergreen-scented twigs.
betula_alleghaniensis.features: Yellowish-bronze bark that peels in thin, curly, horizontal strips. Leaves are ovate with doubly serrated margins that turn golden yellow in fall.

betula_jacqemontii.description: Medium-sized deciduous tree prized for its stunning white bark that remains brilliant even as the tree matures.
betula_jacqemontii.features: Brilliant white bark that does not peel extensively. Ovate, sharply-pointed leaves with serrated edges that turn yellow in fall.

betula_lenta.description: Medium-sized deciduous tree with dark, cherry-like bark and wintergreen-scented twigs and bark.
betula_lenta.features: Dark, shiny bark that resembles cherry tree bark. Twigs and inner bark contain oil of wintergreen, giving a distinctive minty scent when crushed.

betula_nigra.description: Fast-growing deciduous tree with attractive exfoliating bark that is resistant to bronze birch borer.
betula_nigra.features: Distinctive peeling salmon-pink to reddish-brown bark. Diamond-shaped, double-toothed leaves turn yellow in fall.

betula_populifolia.description: Small to medium deciduous tree often growing in clumps, with chalky white bark marked with triangular black patches.
betula_populifolia.features: Chalky-white bark with distinctive black triangular patches at branch junctions. Triangular leaves with long, tapering tips that tremble in the wind.

broussonettia_papyrifera.description: Deciduous tree historically used for paper-making in Asia, with rough-textured leaves and orange spherical fruits.
broussonettia_papyrifera.features: Rough, sandpaper-textured leaves that may be unlobed, mitten-shaped, or with multiple lobes. Separate male and female trees, with females producing orange, spherical fruits.

carpinus_betulus.description: Medium-sized deciduous tree with distinctive fluted trunk and dense foliage, commonly used for formal hedges and screens.
carpinus_betulus.features: Smooth, gray bark with muscle-like fluting. Doubly serrated leaves with deep veins that create a pleated appearance.

carpinus_caroliniana.description: Small understory tree with smooth, muscle-like bark and blue-gray color, also known as Musclewood or Blue Beech.
carpinus_caroliniana.features: Smooth, sinewy, gray-blue bark that resembles flexed muscles. Doubly serrated leaves turn orange, red, and yellow in fall.

carya_cordiformis.description: Large deciduous tree with distinctive sulfur-yellow buds and compound leaves, producing bitter nuts.
carya_cordiformis.features: Compound leaves with 7-11 leaflets. Distinctive bright sulfur-yellow winter buds and thin-shelled bitter nuts within a thin husk.

carya_glabra.description: Large deciduous tree with compound leaves and small, pear-shaped nuts with thin husks.
carya_glabra.features: Compound leaves with 5-7 leaflets that turn golden yellow in fall. Produces small, pear-shaped or oval nuts with thin husks that split only partially when ripe.

carya_ovata.description: Large deciduous tree easily recognized by its shaggy, peeling bark and edible nuts.
carya_ovata.features: Distinctive shaggy bark that peels away in long strips, giving the tree its name. Compound leaves with 5 (rarely 7) leaflets and edible nuts enclosed in thick husks.

carya_tomentosa.description: Large deciduous tree with compound leaves and thick-shelled nuts, known for its strong wood used in tool handles.
carya_tomentosa.features: Compound leaves with 7-9 leaflets, hairy on the underside. Produces nuts with very thick shells inside thick husks, making them difficult to crack.

castanea_dentata.description: Once-dominant forest tree decimated by chestnut blight in the early 1900s, now surviving mostly as understory sprouts.
castanea_dentata.features: Long, lance-shaped leaves with distinctive curved teeth along the edges. Produces sweet, edible nuts enclosed in spiny burs.

catalpa_bignonioides.description: Medium-sized deciduous tree known for its large heart-shaped leaves, showy white flowers, and long bean-like seed pods.
catalpa_bignonioides.features: Massive heart-shaped leaves up to 12 inches wide. Clusters of white, bell-shaped flowers with purple and yellow spots inside, followed by slender bean-like pods up to 20 inches long.

catalpa_speciosa.description: Large deciduous tree with huge heart-shaped leaves, showy white flowers, and long, pencil-thin seed pods.
catalpa_speciosa.features: Enormous heart-shaped leaves arranged in whorls of three. White orchid-like flowers with purple and yellow spots, followed by slender, bean-like seed pods that can reach 2 feet in length.

cedrus_atlantica.origin: Atlas Mountains of Algeria and Morocco
cedrus_atlantica.description: Large, majestic evergreen conifer with a pyramidal form when young, becoming flat-topped with age.
cedrus_atlantica.features: Stiff, bluish-green or silvery-blue needles in clusters on short spur branches. Produces barrel-shaped upright cones that disintegrate at maturity.

cedrus_deodara.description: Large evergreen conifer with graceful, drooping branches and blue-green needles.
cedrus_deodara.features: Drooping leader and branch tips give a weeping appearance. Needles are longer than other cedars, arranged in clusters on spur branches.

cedrus_libani.origin: Mountains of Lebanon, Syria, and Turkey
cedrus_libani.description: Majestic evergreen conifer with historical significance, developing a distinctive flat-topped crown with age.
cedrus_libani.features: Dark green needles in clusters on spur branches. Develops a characteristic flat-topped, layered crown with horizontally spreading branches as it matures.

celtis_occidentalis.description: Medium to large deciduous tree with distinctive warty bark and asymmetrical leaves, highly adaptable to urban conditions.
celtis_occidentalis.features: Distinctive warty, corky projections on gray bark. Leaves are asymmetrical at the base and feel sandpaper-rough on top. Produces small, dark purple drupes that are sweet and edible.

celtis_tenuifolia.description: Small deciduous tree or large shrub with warty bark and smaller leaves than the common hackberry.
celtis_tenuifolia.features: Warty, gray bark similar to common hackberry but smaller in all aspects. Leaves are asymmetrical at the base and produces small, orange-red to purple fruits.

cercidiphyllum_japonicum.description: Medium to large deciduous tree with heart-shaped leaves that emit a sweet fragrance when falling in autumn, reminiscent of cotton candy or burnt sugar.
cercidiphyllum_japonicum.features: Heart-shaped leaves emerge reddish-purple in spring, mature to bluish-green in summer, and turn yellow to apricot in fall. Separate male and female trees, with females producing small banana-shaped pods.

cercis_canadensis.description: Small deciduous tree known for its stunning display of magenta-pink flowers that bloom directly on the branches in early spring before the leaves emerge.
cercis_canadensis.features: Heart-shaped leaves that emerge after the flowers. Produces clusters of pea-like magenta-pink flowers all along the branches, even on the trunk (cauliflory).

chamaecyparis_pisifera.description: Evergreen conifer with numerous cultivars featuring diverse growth habits, foliage types, and colors.
chamaecyparis_pisifera.features: Scale-like foliage in flattened sprays. Many cultivars exist with golden, blue, or thread-like foliage and varying growth forms from dwarf to tall pyramidal.

chamaecyparis_thyoides.description: Slender evergreen conifer native to coastal wetlands, with blue-green foliage and fibrous, reddish-brown bark.
chamaecyparis_thyoides.features: Flattened sprays of blue-green, scale-like foliage that may turn bronzy in winter. Produces small, bluish, berry-like cones about 1/4 inch in diameter.

chionanthus_retusus.description: Small deciduous tree or large shrub covered with showy, white, fringe-like flowers in late spring.
chionanthus_retusus.features: Leathery, dark green leaves and exfoliating bark that reveals an orange-brown inner layer. Produces cloud-like clusters of fragrant white flowers with strap-like petals.

chionanthus_virginicus.description: Small deciduous tree or large shrub noted for its cloud-like display of fragrant white flowers in spring.
chionanthus_virginicus.features: Loose, airy clusters of fragrant white flowers with thin, ribbon-like petals that give a fringe-like appearance. Produces blue-black olive-like fruits on female plants.

cladrastis_lutea.description: Medium-sized deciduous tree with smooth gray bark and pendulous clusters of fragrant white flowers.
cladrastis_lutea.features: Smooth, gray bark resembling beech. Compound leaves turn bright yellow in fall. Produces dramatic, pendulous clusters of fragrant white flowers similar to wisteria.

cornus_florida.description: Small deciduous tree famous for its showy white or pink bracts surrounding small central flowers in spring.
cornus_florida.features: Four showy white or pink petal-like bracts surrounding the true flowers in spring. Red fruits in fall and distinctive alligator-skin textured bark on mature trees.

cornus_kousa.description: Small deciduous tree that flowers about a month later than flowering dogwood, with pointed bracts and raspberry-like red fruits.
cornus_kousa.features: Star-shaped, pointed white bracts appear after the leaves emerge. Produces unusual raspberry-like red fruits and exhibits exfoliating mottled bark with age.

cornus_mas.description: Large shrub or small tree that blooms very early in spring with clusters of small yellow flowers, followed by edible cherry-like fruits.
cornus_mas.features: Small yellow flowers in late winter before the leaves emerge. Produces oblong, cherry-like red fruits that are edible and traditionally used for preserves and syrups.

corylus_colurna.description: Medium-sized deciduous tree with pyramidal form, deeply furrowed cork-like bark, and edible hazelnuts.
corylus_colurna.features: Distinctive corky, gray-brown bark with deep furrows. Produces edible hazelnuts enclosed in deeply cut, bristly husks.

crataegus_crus-galli.description: Small deciduous tree with glossy leaves, white flowers, red fruits, and fearsome thorns.
crataegus_crus-galli.features: Glossy, leathery leaves that turn orange-red in fall. Produces clusters of white flowers followed by bright red fruits that persist into winter. Armed with long, straight thorns up to 3 inches long.

crataegus_laevigata.description: Small deciduous tree with lobed leaves, thorny branches, and clusters of white or pink flowers followed by red fruits.
crataegus_laevigata.features: Leaves with 3-5 shallow lobes. Produces white or pink flowers in spring, followed by bright red fruits. Branches armed with sharp thorns.

ginkgo_biloba.description: Ancient deciduous tree with distinctive fan-shaped leaves, extremely resistant to pests, diseases, and urban pollution.
ginkgo_biloba.features: Unique fan-shaped leaves with parallel veins that turn brilliant yellow in fall. Dioecious species with separate male and female trees (female trees produce malodorous fruits).

liquidambar_styraciflua.origin: Eastern North America, Mexico and Central America
liquidambar_styraciflua.description: Medium to large deciduous tree known for its star-shaped leaves with spectacular fall color and spiky seed balls.
liquidambar_styraciflua.features: Glossy, star-shaped leaves with five pointed lobes that turn vibrant purple, red, orange, and yellow in fall. Produces hard, spiny seed balls that persist through winter.

magnolia_grandiflora.description: Majestic evergreen tree with large, fragrant white flowers and glossy, leathery leaves.
magnolia_grandiflora.features: Large, glossy dark green leaves with rusty-brown undersides. Produces spectacular fragrant white flowers up to 12 inches across throughout summer.

metasequoia_glyptostroboides.description: Deciduous conifer once thought extinct until discovered alive in 1944. Fast-growing with feathery foliage and distinctive buttressed trunk.
metasequoia_glyptostroboides.features: Soft, feathery foliage arranged in opposite pairs that turns russet-brown before dropping in fall. Develops a buttressed base and furrowed reddish-brown bark with age.

picea_abies.description: Large, fast-growing evergreen conifer with distinctive drooping branchlets, commonly used as Christmas trees and windbreaks.
picea_abies.features: Dark green needles and large pendulous cones up to 6 inches long. Branches spread horizontally with distinctive drooping branchlets.

picea_orientalis.description: Slow-growing evergreen conifer with dense, compact growth and short, glossy dark green needles.
picea_orientalis.features: Very short, glossy dark green needles densely covering the branches. Forms a neat pyramidal shape with somewhat pendulous branches.

picea_pungens.description: Evergreen conifer known for its distinctive blue-gray foliage and perfect pyramidal form.
picea_pungens.features: Stiff, sharp needles ranging in color from green to intense silvery-blue. Produces cylindrical light brown cones and maintains a perfect pyramidal shape.

pinus_strobus.description: Tall, fast-growing evergreen with soft, blue-green needles in bundles of five.
pinus_strobus.features: Soft, flexible needles and cylindrical cones. Develops distinctive horizontal branching pattern with age.

quercus_rubra.description: Fast-growing deciduous oak with excellent shade properties and fall color.
quercus_rubra.features: Leaves with 7-11 pointed lobes that turn russet-red in autumn. Straight trunk with dark, furrowed bark.

robinia_pseudo-acacia.description: Fast-growing deciduous tree with fragrant white flowers and compound leaves, known for its extremely durable wood.
robinia_pseudo-acacia.features: Compound leaves with oval leaflets that close at night or during rain. Produces hanging clusters of fragrant white pea-like flowers followed by flat, brown seed pods.

salix_babylonica.description: Medium to large deciduous tree with distinctive pendulous branches that create a graceful, weeping appearance.
salix_babylonica.features: Long, narrow leaves on slender, flexible branches that sweep downward, sometimes reaching the ground. Fast-growing with yellow-brown bark.

salix_nigra.description: Largest native North American willow species, typically found along streams, lakes, and wetlands. Fast-growing and important for stabilizing streambanks and providing wildlife habitat.
salix_nigra.features: Long, narrow, finely serrated leaves with yellowish-green color. Dark, rough, fissured bark that becomes black with age. Produces catkins in spring. Wood is lightweight, soft, and weak but resistant to splitting.

tsuga_canadensis.description: Graceful evergreen conifer with small, flat needles and delicate drooping branches, creates dense shade.
tsuga_canadensis.features: Short, flat needles with two white bands on the underside. Small cones and feathery branch tips that droop gracefully. Bark becomes deeply furrowed with age.

ulmus_americana.description: Once-dominant street tree with distinctive vase-shaped form, severely affected by Dutch elm disease.
ulmus_americana.features: Classic vase-shaped crown with arching branches. Doubly serrated, asymmetrical leaves and distinctive flaky bark with alternating light and dark layers.

zelkova_serrata.description: Deciduous tree often planted as an elm substitute, with vase-shaped crown and serrated leaves.
zelkova_serrata.features: Elm-like leaves with serrated edges that turn bronze, red, or orange in fall. Smooth gray bark when young that develops vertical patches with age.
